title: Boris Johnson’s Brexit plan passes through Commons with majority of 30
text:
Boris Johnson’s Withdrawal Agreement Bill went up against parliament today (Picture: PA)

MPs have voted through Boris Johnson’s EU Withdrawal Bill with 329 votes to 299, creating a majority of 30.

The 110-page document, which also contains an additional 125 pages of additional notes, was read in the Commons for the first time last night.

It is intended to ‘implement, and make other provision in connection with, the agreement between the United Kingdom and the EU’ during Brexit and gives Boris’ deal legal status.

MPs will now be tasked with voting for the government’s proposed timetable for the bill, which currently shows it being implemented in less than three days.

The programme motion gives the House of Lords enough time to consider the bill over the weekend, boosting the government’s chances of delivering Brexit by the Halloween deadline.

Labour will not be supporting the proposed timetable for the bill (Picture: PA)

However, Labour have already made it clear that they would not be supporting the process and accused Boris of trying to ‘force’ it through.

In a letter signed by Chief Whip Nicholas Brown, they stated that the proposed schedule did not allow enough time for ‘sufficient scrutiny’ the deal’s legal text.

The sentiments have been echoed by the DUP and numerous cross-party MPs, voiced their outrage at the tight schedule last night.

Rory Stewart, who was among the 21 rebels exiled from the Tories for voting to make a no-deal Brexit illegal, suggested he would not back the programme motion.

Former Tory Chancellor Ken Clarke slammed the time allocated as ‘plainly quite insufficient’ and SNP Commons leader Pete Wishart called the schedule ‘totally unacceptable’.

Both remain and leave protesters have been outside parliament today (Picture: Rex Features)

While Green MP Caroline Lucas labelled the timetable ‘frankly outrageous’, tweeting: ‘You couldn’t make this up.’

Earlier today Boris threatened to pull the Withdrawal Agreement Bill entirely if MPs do not vote in favour of the timetable.

The government have also refused to rule out the ‘nuclear option’ if the deal is changed beyond all recognition through amendments in the Commons.

Boris said: ‘I will in no way allow months more of this. If Parliament refuses to allow Brexit to happen, and instead gets its way and decides to delay everything until January or possible longer.

‘In no circumstances can the government continue with this.’

The prime minister stated that the UK would have to ‘go forward to a general election’ if the bill was pulled by the government.
